B., dated 4th March 1905, and in continuation of my telegram of 14th instant, I have the honour to report the action taken by me in the direction of advising the Sheikh of Koweit to adopt a distinctive flag for use on vessels belonging to himself or his subjects. 2 . I first broached the subject with Sheikh Mubarak at the end of April, hut he was out in camp at the time and as there was little privacy to he got, it was not possible to discuss patterns in detail. He did not like the idea at first, on the ground that his people would not know what to make of the change, and that such a course would increase the enmity of the Turks towards him For n h vp* uld not a^ree to a fin^ of new design, but 1 explained that this did not seem essential : that all that was required was for his dhows to carry a flag that could he unmistakably recognised as his, and the use of which would make it impossible for Customs Officials at Persian Gulf and other ports to say that they could not distinguish Koweit dhows from any other craft flying the Star and Crescent. I went on to suggest that some addition to, or variation of, the flag that he now hoisted would perhaps meet the case and asked him to let me make out some specimens for him, and also designs for ships, articles which might a'so he useful in conjunction with the flag. To this he agreed, and I had intended to arrange the details in communication with the Political Agent. Unfortunately however Captain Knox fell ill with appendicitis a few days later and subsequently proceeded on leave, and as the matter was of some delicacy it seemed advisable to wait for an opportunity to conclude negotiations with him myself. This I have now done. 3. I had a long interview with Sheikh Mubarak regarding this and other matters on 12th instant. I first showed him the four flags of which speci mens accompany. Of these No. A, in a book of recent date in my possession, is shown as the Standard of the Khedive of Egypt, and I thought it might be of interest to Sheikh Mubarak to see that though the device was still broadly speak ing that of the Star and Crescent, it was easily distinguishable from the flag which he now flies. 1 then showed him the other three and discussed the merits of each with him. He came to the conclusion that No. 1, the Turkish flag with Koweit written across it in the Arabic character, was the simplest pattern for him to adopt, but he did not make any special objections to either of the others, and if Government consider that a greater divergence from the flag would be advisable, I have little doubt that he v\ ould accept any reasonable modification without demur, e.g., the Crescent or the 3 Crescent design, or either of them with Koweit written across it as in the pattern selected. A different type of flag altogether, except it be the British Flag, he will not accept, of that I feel sure. If the flag chosen is approved I think it would be an easier flag to make if the Arabic letters of Koweit were in a little larger type, and if I arrange to have a seal-pattern made up here, perhaps sanction could be accorded to my indenting on the Ordnance Department for others, as in the case of the Trucial Chiefs. 4 . Monsieur Waffelaert appears to be under the impression that any native craft can be searched in any place on suspicion of having e< contraband ” on board. The Sheikh’s “ boom ” plies between Kowait and Eao taking mails, bring ing firewood, etc., and even if it had firearms on board, it seems to me that the matter would lie between Sheikh Mubarek and the Turkish authorities. The action of the Muzaffer undoubtedly caused a great deal of irritation throughout the Arab Coast, and if such high handed actions on the part of the Customs continue, I think the Arabs may possibly attempt some kind of reprisals. If therefore the Government of India agree that indiscriminate searching of native craft in the Shat el Arab is contrary to International Law and custom, I trust that they will be pleased to take steps to prevent the Persian Customs Department from abusing the rights of search in this way. Dated the 3rd November 1904. p r0 tn —Monsieur E. Waffelaert, Director-General of Customs, Bushire, To— Captain A. P. Trevor, First Assistant to the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf. In continuation of my letter No. 6642 of the 27th ultimo I beg to state that from the inquiry instituted from the Commander of S. S. Muzaffer it follows that the boat has detained many «* booms ” and “Bellums ” but has never kept them longer than it was necessary for searching the inside of the craft. The Commander of our boat does not recollect anything particular about the boom Mosalim, but the mere fact of the crew’s shouting out that the vessel belonged to Sheikh Mubarek was not sufficient to prove that the boat did not carry contraband goods. Besides, beyond searching in the boat no barm whatever has been done neither to the craft or to the crew.No. 397, d&ted Bushire, the 20th November 1904. From—The Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, To—The Secretary to the Government of India in the Foreign Department, In confirmation of my telegram of the 14th Novemher 1904,1 have the honour to state, for the information of the Government of India, that the Director-General of Customs has informed me that the Koweit dhow belong ing to Abdul Aziz bin Farah of Koweit, which has been detained here, will now be confiscated. Instructions have been issued by the Central Customs Administration that the Nakhoda of the dhow will be imprisoned until the fine of 18,000 krans is paid, or until further orders. 2 . I submit that this is an exceedingly high-handed proceeding as there was absolutely no evidence brought forward at the investigation at Moham- merah {vide Mr. Consul McDouall’s report sent with my letter No. 341, dated 1 st October 1904) to show that the rifles were intended for Persia. 3. There were on board the dhow 4 hales of canvas belonging to one Haji Mukhbil of Bahrein consigned by him to Suleiman bin Mahmud-el Thakeir of Busreh, and it was in connection with a request made by me that Haji Mukhbil’s canvas should be returned, that the question of Article IY of the Act of 5th Eamzan came up. mods.abstract: The papers concern the proposal that vessels from Koweit [Kuwait] should adopt a distinctive flag, and the likely reaction this would bring from the Government of Turkey [the Ottoman Empire].The principal correspondents are the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf (Major Percy Zachariah Cox); the Political Agent, Kuwait (Captain Stuart George Knox); the British Ambassador at Constantinople (Sir Nicholas Roderick O'Conor); and senior officials of Government of India.The papers cover: correspondence concerning the question of the protection that the British Government should give to subjects of Kuwait in Persian territory, June-December 1904 (folios 220-246); a report that the Ambassador at Constantinople saw no objection to the adoption by the Shaikh of Kuwait [Mubārak bin Jābir Āl Ṣabāḥ] of a distinctive flag for Kuwait vessels, while retaining his existing flag for use in Kuwait, February-March 1905 (folios 217-219); correspondence concerning the proposed use by the Shaikh of Kuwait of the Turkish flag with the addition of the word 'Koweit' written across it in Arabic letters (including colour drawings of the proposed flag, folios 199-203), and specimen shipping certificate, July 1905 - July 1906 (folios 190-216); and correspondence concerning the Shaikh of Kuwait's concerns over the likely consequences of his adoption of the new flag, particularly his fears of 'oppressive measures' from Turkish officials at Basrah [Basra] and other Turkish ports, August 1906 - March 1907 (folios 176-188).The Arabic language content of the papers is confined to Arabic wording on the specimen shipping certificate and drawings of the proposed Kuwait flag, between folios 192 and 201.The date range gives the covering dates of all the documents; the date range of the Secret Department minute papers given on the subject divider on folio 171 is 1905-07.
